captions.text: [MUSIC CHARITY VANCE, "LOVE ME"]
-Hey guys, it's Brooklyn.

And today I'm going to
be teaching you guys how
I put my contacts in and out.

I got a few comments asking
me to do a video about this,

and since I do have
contacts, I thought
I'd be able to make this video.

And I'm just going to be showing
you guys how I put them in

and how take them out,
and how I clean them.
And all that fun stuff.

But first, I want to tell
you the story of my contacts.

Which is basically, when I
first started using contacts,
all that fun stuff.

I think I was nine maybe, I
don't remember how old I was.
How old was I?
I don't even remember.
Some young age, below nine.

That I realized I
could not see clearly

without like glasses,
or something.

And so we got glasses, and I
remember telling my mom, whoa,

I can actually see the
leaves on the trees.

I can actually see all
the details of the world.
It's pretty awesome.

My mom thought that
was pretty funny.

But after a while, glasses
got kind of annoying.

You had to carry them
around, take them on and off,
all that stuff.
So we decided to get contacts.

And I remember the first
time I tried to put them in,
I was having such a hard time.

I seriously could
not put them in.

I finally got them in
and then by the time

it was time for me
to take them out,

I didn't want them
to take them out.

Because I was just like, it
took me so let me put them in,
I didn't want to take them out.

So since my mom did
not have contacts,

and neither does my dad, neither
of them even have bad eyesight.
They did not know how to do it.

So I had to go to
a friend's house

and she had to lay
me down on the bed,

and literally pull the
contact from my eye.

Because I would
not do it myself.

And then after
that, she taught me

how to take them in,
how to take them out.

And I just sat in
front of the mirror

and practiced for an hour,
so I would know how to do it.

And then a couple days later,
is still took me a half an hour

to take them in
and put them out.

Now I can do in like 10
seconds, because it's
been like since I was nine.
How many years is that?
A long time.
Seven or something like that.
Anyways.
It's been awhile.
Five.
Five years.
Thank you.
It's been a while.

So, yeah that's
kind of my story.

So I will show you
guys how I do that.

Start off, the
saline solution I use

is called Multipurpose
Solution, from Costco.

And I want to show you
guys my contact case.
And I got this at Forever 21.

And you put your
contacts in here.
It's got a little mirror.
Keeps it safe.

And then I was going
to show you guys,

on your contact case, your
real original contact case,
it has a blue and white top.

And this is for
people astigmatism.

Astigmatism is when one eye
has worse eye sight, basically.

And so you have to get
two different contacts.

And if you get
them mixed up, you

won't be able to see
because one eye will

have the wrong contact, and
it'll be a whole jumbled mess.
So they do this.

They make one blue,
and one white,

and it's so you know that the
right one is the blue one,

and the left one
is the white one,

so you won't get your
contacts mixed up.

Luckily, I do not
have a astigmatism,

so I do not need to
bother with that.

But for those of you do, be sure
you put them in the right spot.

Bailey, on hand, does
have astigmatism,
so she uses this a lot.

So you are not alone, if
you have a astigmatism.

Bailey has one too,
so don't feel bad.
OK.

Now I'm going to
show you guys how

I put my contacts
in in the morning.

And it usually takes me a little
while, only like five minutes
or so, not too long.
Op, slippery.

Sometimes it's hard to
get them out of here,

because they are all
covered in solution,

and they're slippery because
I have the soft contacts.

I was going to tell you I
have the monthly contacts.

And you can wear them for a
month, and they won't go bad.

Yeah, but some people
have the daily contacts,

where they put
them in in the day,

and then they have to change
them daily, and stuff.
I don't know.

I don't do those, so
if you do those, cool,

but I was just going to say that
I take my contacts out at night

because I feel like
it's more cleaner.

I don't know, I feel
better, more awake

if I put them in in the
morning, but is totally
OK if you keep them in at night.

I just have a weird habit,
I take them out at night.
OK.

So I'm going to
pull my contact out,

and I'm going to place it
so that the edges curl up
on my finger.

And sometimes you can fill
it with contact solution,
if it's not already filled.

Sometimes it's easier
for it to go on your eye

if it has a few drops
of contact solution.

And sometimes, a
little too much.

You're going to turn,
take your middle finger,

pull your lid down,
and then you're

just going to want to take
your finger with the contact

on, it and place it in
the middle of your eye.

And it'll feel weird, and
cool, but that's totally OK.

And then your just
going to want to blink.

And it will look like I'm
crying, but I'm not crying.

I promise I'm not sad,
no theatrics here.

It makes your eye,
sometimes it will

make your eye red,
that's perfectly fine.
It will go away.

It's just because it's
like the effects of crying

because it's salt
water in your eye.

Is totally fine. and I'm sorry
if my mascara is running,

because I wore make
up for you guys.
Normally I don't wear my makeup.

I put this in the morning
when I wake up out of my bed.

But I wore make up for
you guys for you guys

so I could be pretty
for the video.

But that is how you
put your contacts in.

After wearing your
contacts all day,
it's time to take them out.

And so I'm just going to take
my saline solution that I used

before, and I'm going
to just dump it out.

And normally I would use a sink,
but since I'm in the studio,

I brought a towel so that
the saline solution does not
go over me.

You're going to take
your case, and you're

going to just rinse this out
a bit with saline solution.
Not a lot.

Just enough that you
can mix it around,

get all the little
germs or whatever

left over from the
used contact solution,
and then dump that out.

And then you're
going to fill it up

with new solution, each
of the little circles.
And you can fill about half way.

You don't need a ton, just
enough that the contact

is submerged enough to
be cleansed all night.

Now you're just going to
reach with your bottom lid.

I usually use my middle finger,
and I just pull my bottom lid

down, and I take my pointer
finger and my thumb,

and I just reach in,
and I grab my contact.

And you can pinch
it, so it kind of

looks like this, which
will look really funny.

And then you just
pull it off your eye.
And there you have your contact.

And you'll place in
one of the circles,

roll it around, put
the lid on, and you're
good to go for the night.

I hope this video helped all
of you who are starting out

of contacts, or
don't wear contact

or were just curious on
how it works of contacts.
I hope this video helped you.

Be sure to comment
below, on other ideas

you have for videos, because
we love taking your ideas
and making them into videos.
It's a ton of fun.

Be sure to subscribe, and see
future videos, because we just

love you guys so much, we want
you to see all of our video.

And we'll see you
guys next week.
Bye.
[MUSIC CHARITY VANCE, "LOVE ME"]
-Good job.
Do it again.
-Hi Mom.
[INAUDIBLE]
-Good job.
Bailey, come on.
-My turn.
-Wow!

comments.text:
Don't thing that I need to say:

Keeping your left and right contacts separate is more important than you 
may think. If you have an eye infection in one eye, if you mix up your 
contacts the eye infection may spread to the other eye. Just be careful to 
keep them separate.﻿

A word to the wise: never get fake nails put on if you do wear contacts. 
They pinch too hard when you remove them and tear tiny slits in the middle 
which hurt immensely if you wear them with the tear. I tore through three 
pairs in two weeks when I had solar nails put on. That was $50 down the 
drain right there.

Great tutorial! :)﻿

comments.author: grace chan

comments.text:
This actually helped me out a lot. I JUST got my contacts today, when I was 
in the eye doctors office...well more like the "practice" area to put 
in/take out your contacts it took me like 3-5 minutes to get my right eye 
contact in, like 3 minutes to get my left contact in my left eye in. NOW 
when I went to take them out the right one took like 8 minutes to get out, 
the left one was an absolute nightmare. Seriously This video made it look 
SO easy. I currently have my contacts out since it is night time. I am kind 
of dreading the morning to put them in in the morning but I am going to use 
the method you used to put them in, use the 2nd method you use to take them 
out. Again thank you for the video it was very helpful, I am going to put 
these methods to the test!﻿
comments.author: XxFirespherexX

comments.text:
+Gracie Glitters You will get them out. The main thing to do when you put 
them in/take them out is to remain calm. Trust me dropping one of your 
contacts is a nightmare. Just be calm, use the method that is most 
comfortable for you to put them in, take them out. You will get it. I have 
wore glasses for over 20 years, it still takes me like 1 minute to get my 
right one in, like 3 minutes to get my left one in, less than 1 minute to 
get them both out. It will take time toi get used to putting them in, 
taking them out.
comments.author: XxFirespherexX
